author: Richa Shukla
title: Jaipur watches women's issues take centrestage
text:
Theatre lovers in the city got to enjoy various plays at Jairangam, a ten-day theatre festival that concluded on Sunday.
READ : Theatre fest takes centre stage in Jaipur
People came in droves to watch the 30-odd plays that were staged, some of them featuring noted film actors. On the concluding day , plays on women-related issues took centrestage, with the likes of Shilpa Shukla and Makarand Deshpande giving stellar performances.
In her solo performance in A Woman Alone , directed by Mohit Tripathi, Shilpa played a housewife who is frustrated, suppressed, and deprived of love. The play showed how in a world dominated by men, women have to go through a lot. Sharing her experience in Jaipur, she said, "I like performing for the Jaipur theatre audience. My work takes me to different places and I have had the chance to explore many new cities. But Rajasthan will always remain a special place for me because I faced the camera for the first time here in Pushkar. Since then, whenever I visit Rajasthan, I make sure I go to Ajmer Sharif and Pushkar's Brahma Temple."
Moon Moon Singh essayed the role of a heartbroken girl in the play Stri Subodhini, directed by Tripurari Sharma. It was another women-centric act that narrated a tale of love and be trayal. Much to the delight of theatre lovers, there was another play staged on the last day, in which actor Makarand Deshpande teamed up with the likes of Yashpal Sharma and Kishor Kadam to entertain the audience.The play, Karodo Mein Ek , written and directed by Deshpande, was based on how a financial crisis changes the dynamics of the relationship be tween the family members.
The audience members were delighted by so many brilliant acts. Simantini Singh, a theatre enthusiast, said, "I personally liked the two plays that had a woman playing the protagonist. They showed the gender biases that exist in our society. All the actors played their parts well, but Shilpa's performance remains my favourite."
